SENT.plain: Cerebral blood volume before and after acetazolamide was measured by SPECT to evaluate cerebral vasodilatory capacity in eight patients with cerebrovascular disease and five control subjects
Two SPECT measurements were performed serially, and acetazolamide was administered between them
The ratio of increase in hemispheric blood volume was calculated, and it was compared with the results of cerebral blood flow and cerebral blood volume measurements
A cerebral vasodilatory capacity map, the image after acetazolamide minus the baseline image, was also produced
Acetazolamide increased hemispheric blood volume in all unilateral carotid disease than in the uninvolved hemispheres of the patients and control subjects
The ratio of concordance with blood flow and blood volume measurements was approximated at 80%
Cerebral vasodilatory capacity mapping revealed three defects compatible with the clinical data
SPECT measurements of cerebral blood volume after acetazolamide can be performed following baseline SPECT with no additional radiotracer, and may be helpful to assess hemodynamic status
